Perhaps, we can make the rest of that network better, polish up the other smaller stations that have fallen into neglect and disrepair. 

There's hope in that vision. And a place for you to promote your work, make new friends, and stay in touch with old ones. 

The railway is still there.

As I keep saying, the choice will be made for you if you don't leave. You'll lose engagement, or you'll get banned. Or both. 

Twitter is not, as one of the most Extremely Online men of our time put it, "the commanding height of culture." 

It's one railway station on a vast network.

And I ask myself, if my goal is to promote my work on a site that's not run by a blatant white supremacist, how can I achieve it? Well, Bluesky is one small part of the answer. An inadequate part, yes, but I got off of Twitter before I was pushed. 

If you're not a Nazi, you'll need to as well.

I'm just asking you to be tactical about all this. I say this as a woman who supplements her income through freelance writing; I need the exposure these platforms give me. Twitter was *very* good for my career.

I still set it aside. I cannot be a part of what that place has become.

When I make this argument, I'm not saying I'm better than you. Goddess knows I'm not. I'm probably more Terminally Online than you. I'm not better, or more moral. You're not a bad person for remaining on Twitter, and I'm not trying to make you feel like one.
It is, in short, making the Nazi bar respectable through your continued presence. *That*, more than anything else, is what he tried to buy for his 44bn dollars.

They make the place important; vital; an essential "town square." Every business, every creative personality, everyone who remains there "for work," every government agency, gives Musk's neo-Stormfront operation the only thing his money can't buy: legitimacy.

But, most of all, Twitter is valuable because you're on it. And it's valuable because the world's celebrities, politicians, journalists, artists, academics, activists, and shitposters hang out there. An epistemic elite.

"Twitter is where the world has a conversation" feels true because of them.

Musk remains the world's richest man, on paper and in fact. For all his travails, he has access to the world's financial institutions and its good graces that 99.9% of the population could only dream of. Nickel and diming him on server costs is... a fanciful hope.

One common excuse I hear from people who remain on Twitter is that they're making it more expensive for Musk to run; the more Twitter users, the more he spends in server costs, the faster it'll go bankrupt.

And, no. 1) Money is no object for him, and 2) that's not Twitter's true value.

I'm a strong advocate of using platforms in ways the owners or VC do not intend. But in Twitter's case it's virtually impossible to do that, save by evading Musk's gaze. And you can't do so forever. After all, you need virality to make Twitter work for you.

This is qualitatively different and worse than pre-Musk Twitter; it's even, in very real ways, worse than Zuckerberg. The owner openly sympathises with Nazis and is extremely blatant about suppressing the left. This is not subtle, or incidental, it's what the platform is *for* now.
I keep saying this: whatever virtuous purpose you have in continuing to use Twitter, the platform itself *will not let you* use it for that end.

And yeah, I think it's clear that I loved this movie overall, but I did not like that bit. Even if I'm glad the resolution was a poly femdom triad--which is why I was more forgiving.

Of course! I give you all the slack! It was a good review. It just helped me cohere some stuff I've been thinking about for a while here. 

I'd definitely be interested in reading you at length on the subject.

Also, as someone who had a falling out with a prominent feminist critic because I wrote an essay about how Bayonetta is Good, Actually, believe me, I've certainly taken my lumps for trying to be nuanced about this sort of thing.

Part of what makes Katie's review thoughtful is that that's the specific thing she alights on as nettlesome in the film's narrative. And it does suck, actually!

But that, again, gets at the core issue. If something's patriarchal here, it's not really the sex.

To me, the big problem with Poor Things is that Emma Stone's character ends up marrying her dirtbag doctor boyfriend in the end. *That* bit felt like something I'd call a patriarchal fantasy (which, to me, is a better term than "male fantasy.")

It gets back to that question of utility. What are we really doing, as critics, when we ask if an artwork is feminist? Or calling something a male fantasy? It's usually shorthand for some other more complex, even nuanced set of ideas.

I think a lot about what's sexy--I write an erotica series, after all. And as a trans woman I've always been particularly sensitive about allegations of "male fantasy." If I find something sexy that someone else tags as a male fantasy, is there something amiss with me? Am I failing at being a woman?

And I want to stress, I don't think Katie's review does either of these things. I think, with an economy of language she does quite a bit better. But it did make me think of these recurring issues I've had with Poor Things critiques.

What makes a sex scene a male fantasy? In my view, it's about power (particularly the man having it), and *what* is being sexualised, more than the actual fact of sexualisation. But a lot of the time, it's used as shorthand for "lady naked."

The second is that the other trope I see with these critiques is some variation on the "this is a male fantasy" argument. Over the years I've also made similar criticisms, but I could never shake the feeling of it being a very "well, I know it when I see it" kind of critique. Unsatisfying.

One is that, as someone who's been doing feminist media criticism for nearly 15 years, I long ago gave up on the idea that "is this art feminist?" is a useful question. And it feels like a lot of Poor Things criticisms rely on it, and the implicit answer of "no" regarding this film.

Characteristically thoughtful review from Ms. Tightpussy. 

But--not to pick on her--it did help me identify one of my biggest problems with the genre of contrarian critiques of Poor Things. Well, two problems, really...

The world's ended so many times, folks. But the credits didn't roll. History simply marched on.

And we can do our part in making it ever so slightly better. It doesn't belong to the worst elements of humanity.

And if you look back at history, at previous crises that we now view through the sepia-tint of black and white photos (1918 Influenza), or the rose coloured glasses of nostalgia (the Blitz), their true stories were far more complex than one may believe, at first.

And staring at social media all day is a good way to lose faith in humanity (I have to remind myself of this *constantly*--my wife had to remind me of this just yesterday). 

It allow for hyperfixation on the worst of us and minimising the best of us.

In reality, we're not in the opening scenes of a disaster movie. It's just another chapter in history's neverending story; a potentially ugly one. But, then, the future's what we make it. Our real lives won't look good on screen, but they will make the world go 'round.

We use references to film to inform our worldviews; it can be fun but, taken too seriously, it's distorting as well.

In this case, it can lead to doomerism. Which, as many actual climate scientists have striven to say, is not helpful in fighting climate change.

Real life doesn't have a beginning, middle, nor end; it's sloppy with its use of tension, it's frequently dull, people flub their lines constantly, and it's oh-so-rare to get a satisfying narrative beat.

Less jokey: reality is far messier. Never utopian, but rarely quite so dire.

Cinematic epistemology strikes again. 

I don't want to pick on this person; the fears are legitimate and I share them sometimes. But it's worth unpacking how often we turn to movies--i.e. tight, constructed narratives designed to produce satisfaction--for these kids of insights. It's not ideal.

4. it's miller time.

they feel listened to. they feel like they've made positive design contributions. they feel like you're approachable and will not be defensive or egotistical about your ideas. they believe you to have good judgement because you could see the positives of their idea.

3. propose to them that you incorporate their idea into your own at the points of compatibility. explain the ways their idea is better, and how you'll include those parts in the final design. make it clear that you understand their goals, and you believe your integrated idea will meet those goals.

2. assume they're right and you're wrong. imagine that you're trying to argue for their idea against a version of yourself. ask yourself: in what ways is their idea better? what goals does it address that mine does not? we both want to make a good game; what is the actual point at which we disagree?

I will accept hugs.

The recent revival of self immolation as a left wing protest tactic strikes me as a function of the political despair that people like Hannah Proctor and Sarah Marcus have identified as the predominant left affect following the failures of the protest movements of the 2010s. A morbid symptom.

I see a lot of sad, depressed people on here, despondent about the state of the professions (as well as the world). I should also say that the way I've spoken out over the last day on this might not have been a pro-gamer move on my part. I'm a freelance writer, after all. It's not impossible that I've burnt a bridge or two here. In a terrible job market!

But I have relevant expertise and I had to say something.

So, yes, in her narrow case I'd argue that followers are a going concern. She will not take over the government, but her ability to crowdsource potential terroristic acts and hate crimes *is* a huge problem, and fame and (the wrong kind of) attention nourish it.

The political power LoTT has comes from mostly conservative mainstream media access and exposure, as well as having been given money and a hand-up from a well-funded right-wing propaganda ecosystem. The terroristic followers she wields constitute her calling card, her credibility, to these people.

Taylor Swift may have many, many more followers on social media and more engagement than LoTT, but her average follower is not a political extremist who is being further radicalised, and, pound-for-pound, is not someone likely to call in a bomb threat (Swifty stereotypes aside).

Last night, Lorenz herself--in a rather ironic twist--tried to tell me that followers are not necessarily a measure of power.

Well, if you know *anything* about my academic hobbyhorses, I agree completely. The issue is the *quality* of LoTT's followers.

My--frankly, very well-founded--fear is that the latter is likelier to win out. If we're lucky, this is a wash. 

Right-wingers are crowing about the interview, but they'd have done that regardless. It remains to be seen whether this did LoTT more favours than not. Her follower count went up.

Charitably, we can say that this fact runs alongside the facts that I'm worried about: i.e., lending fuel to LoTT's social media fire and aiding recruitment of more people willing to terrorise schools and hospitals.

It's a question of which force will be more salient in the wake of the interview.

Probably the best argument in favour of Lorenz's approach has come from Gillian's points about how the freakishness of LoTT-types scare wavering ordinary voters back into the fold.

What I can say is, after all this nonsense, I sincerely hope so because what's done is done.

And then the term "accountability" and its meaningless works perfectly to aid that cause. It rallies people together who otherwise would never agree on actual *outcomes* because you never get that far. Meanwhile, their target just gets battered endlessly.

This would be a problem except the "movement" never gets far enough to actually call for practical action. They never do; that's online activism. Zeno's Paradox for political goals.

So instead it just remains all about the mobbing, the *demand* for accountability that can never be satisfied.

For some, accountability means a simple "I'm sorry," for others it's a "sincere apology" (defined differently than how the person next to them defines a "sincere apology," of course), or it may be material or emotional recompense, or it may mean fucking off and dying.

This. But also, if an online mob gets large enough, "accountability" is a useful standard to rally folks with; it means whatever they want it to mean. Ask ten people what accountability looks like in a given case and you'll get twenty different answers.

It's good for crowdsourcing and nothing more.

I... agree partially. I think you're generally right. The grass-touching population is different. But I think a lot of online activists aren't (knowingly) clout-chasing. I think they're sincere. Their pain comes from a real place of empathy and compassion. It's just misdirected.

The last 15 years are littered--worldwide--with the wreckage of movements that though social media activism was the One Weird Trick for making world-historical change. 

Don't fall for the trap again.

If there's any advice I can give, it's this: ensure that the platform's features are equal to the task of achieving your goals. 

That, in short, it really is the right tool for the job.

Because most times, I promise you it isn't.

Platforms like this do *not* create polities; they do *not* create communities of people ready to rule, or even seriously alter the relations of ruling.

But they can crowdsource, and you can, say, direct money at a worthy cause that way.

If you come to some kind of answer that reduces to "raising awareness," it's probably not going to help your cause much--especially if it's something that's, say, already dominating the front pages of the world's newspapers. There's no awareness left to raise.

Social media can do a few things well. 

And if you are sincerely interested in using for activism--or just helping others--you have to ask if your goals are a match for the platform's affordances.

Can the features of a platform really help your goals?

We've been told for years that social media is the royal road to "changing the world." Yet it affords us very little in that regard.

It allows us to *post*; endlessly. And so we confuse that for political activity; for praxis. Because if it's not those things, well, have we wasted our time?

This belief that the only way you can fix things is by performing awareness and keeping yourself glued to the information firehose of global news til you're a gibbering wreck is precisely why so many young activists feel like change is hopeless and they burn out by their early 20s

Basically, the kind of unwanted attention the social media lottery favours us all with at one time or another.

And we're meant to put up with it; the lords of tech believe this is how things should be.

Buuuuut... we do like the *upside* of it all. The good serendipity.

For obvious reasons, this also leads to bullshit, which we've all run afoul of one way or another. People being overly familiar, people butting in, or just 'serendipitously' picking up harassment, reply guys, non-specified parasocial relationships, etc.

What makes microblogging so fun and, frankly, addicting for people is that it is arguably the most serendipitous of all social media designs. You can be riffing with a friend and out of nowhere some stranger adds a really good joke, e.g.

When you're at a cafe chatting with friends, it's rude for strangers to come up, sit down at your little table, and start talking to you at length.

But open platforms aren't like that. Anyone *can* pull up a chair; this is encouraged, and we actually *like this* feature at certain times.

One of the... quriks of social media (at the root of many of its problems) is that most people have expectations for their social interactions that are at variance with open social media's very design.

We think of it like sitting with friends at a cafe; but these platforms aren't built that way.

While I think Stancil expresses some ambivalence about his 'strategy' in the Racket interview (to his credit), it's clear he believes the dogged, endless posting is achieving some kind of measurable good in the world. 

It's not. It just creates value for platforms.

And this is the quality he shares with many leftists who absolutely despise him, who also fundamentally agree that they need to participate in these spaces for nebulously 'political' reasons. "Visibility," "accountability," "making their voices heard," etc.

Twitter's public relevance has declined steadily because of what Musk did to the place--what Stancil and those like him are doing is calling (without realising it) for the application of emergency brakes to arrest this decline.

And when it comes to some of the nettlesome second-order effects of this crap leaking into mainstream media, that's more easily resolved by members of the epistemic elite engaging *less*, not *more* on such platforms.

What that *does* is help keep the site going a little longer, and sprinkles it with the pixie dust of respectability that comes from every non-Nazi user. 

But this is not, in point of fact, where the battle of persuasion is currently being waged.

Because of Elon Musk's policies, Twitter has now attracted a lot of ever more openly Nazi chuds to flood the platform and be open about their chudery. But that's not the same as 'organising.'

And the idea that liberals or the left need to 'organise' there in response is bogus.

What he identifies here is *not* organising. That is not how these Steve Sailer types 'organise'; they do so the old-fashioned and genuinely effective way--with money and links to real political power.

Twitter, like all open social media, *crowdsources*; that's not the same thing.

Here's some skeets of his from today that are further examples of the genre. 

Far be it from me to begrudge him wasting the time of far right race-science-loving freaks, of course. But there's some major problems with first principles here. And some misunderstanding of social media.

This is ex post facto justification for being Extremely Online; "I participate in the Twitter/Bluesky discourse cycle; I wouldn't do anything that wasn't politically important; therefore this *must* be politically important--maybe even activism!"

These are key examples of the genre, and part of why I've strongly encouraged mainstream journalists to spend less time on these platforms and to reduce their sourcing from them.

But also, the idea that Twitter's "consensus" is any kind of useful proxy for the polity is... really, really wrong.

In his Racket interview he spends a fair bit of time justifying his Twitter (and, ostensibly, BSky) addiction. Whatever else may be said of him, these justifications constitute a view that I feel even his most ardent detractors fundamentally share--and that's why it's a problem.

Therefore, re: the Extremely Online Left predilection for owning the libs, the Russians didn't create that. It was, and remains, an existing tendency that emerges out of well-meaning personal biases. Occasionally a few malefactors may exploit that, but they don't really *need* to.

Russian social media interference is real. But the way it works is by aggravating existing, widespread points of tension in loosely-regulated social media environments. It does not create anything that isn't already there organically.

Some liberals will, naturally, blame that source of all the 21st Century's ills: Russia. But nothing is ever that simple. As a social media researcher who has colleagues that helped prove Russian interference on social media, I still cringe inwardly at that reflex because it's so simplistic.

These things come in waves, like most social media campaigns. People get swept up. They get bombarded on their timelines and a virtuous cycle of posting results. I think that, for most, it's sincere. But why does the wave go out with Republicans and other assorted aspiring fascists?

Does the tide of western social media leftist critique on US foreign policy go out when aspiring fascists are in charge? And if so, why? I don't think it happens because of deliberate hypocrisy, though there are many particularly vengeful liberals and centrists who want to believe that.
Among that Extremely Online set, there remains a collective unwillingness to stare the *actual* aspirants to fascism in the face and confront their designs. It was, and remains, deeply worrying.

Sure, some of them were cringe. Some were grifters. But it was telling that there was (and remains) real ferment there that a lot of leftist organisers just refused to take advantage of; it was easier to make memes and comics about 'cringe' pink pussy hats.

A lot of the snark on western leftist social media was directed at Hillary Clinton ahead of the 2016 election; some of it continued to dog Trump afterwards, but the great bulk of it shifted to mocking the "resistance" liberals who mobilized to oppose Trump.

There's a path that can be charted here, where Glenn Greenwald was an unstinting critic of American foreign policy during the Obama administration... and an unstinting critic of how Democrats responded to Trump during *his* administration. It's a path many followed.

But if one wants to focus on the comic and related satires: where was the replacement that mocked the hypocrisy of Trump's "isolationism" vs. his dramatic escalation of American militarism? "Ah, I hear this drone is being sent by an isolationist!"
The comic is not the point; it's the moral position it represented. A lot of social media-driven criticism of the drone war dried up when Trump escalated it.

If you want to win on policy, you need to tell people what you're *giving* them rather than what you're *taking away*. Decarbonisation is vital for the planet, but it can also make everyone's standard of living truly incredible--and that's worth emphasising.

If you tell people the only way to solve a major problem is to sacrifice indefinitely, and it isn't even *true*... well, I can't overstate the degree to which you're screwing yourself on policy. 

At the risk of stating the obvious, this is also about COVID.

There is, however, another way--call it a "Green Plenty" approach--that emphasises all the ways in which our lives would be materially *better* if we decarbonised. Walkable cities, the end of planned obsolescence, cheaper (or free) energy, and so on.

There is, however, another way--call it a "Green Plenty" approach--that emphasises all the ways in which our lives would be materially *better* if we decarbonised. Walkable cities, the end of planned obsolescence, cheaper (or free) energy, and so on.

The troubling legacy of this is that it leads to what I call "sacrifice-first" approaches to structural problems--the idea that, in this case, solving climate change requires a massive degradation in everyone's standard of living.

Getting a gun is glamorous. But it's a titanic responsibility--the power to end a life always is. Marksmanship is only the first step. In order to be of use to your community you'll need to cultivate many, many other skills in order to be *effective* with the gun (rather than another threat).

We look to the past and valorise armed minorities and antifascists--Jews fighting back against Nazis, the French Resistance, the Black Panthers. But the Panthers also filled the gaps left behind by schools and social services. The Resistance had spies and linguists and moles and medics.

The utility of a bunch of people alone at home sitting on private gun collections is minimal in terms of community defence (and still opens them up to all the risks of private gun ownership--hurting themselves or loved ones).

But if you're well trained and part of something larger? Well...

Beyond that, we should be clear-eyed about this: a lot of "citizen journalists" can be (often unwitting) sources of misinformation and, without curation, can be as much a part of the problem as the solution.
But I am increasingly interested in following such people through blogs again, and I see no reason why Bluesky or Mastodon can't become smaller but still-workable clearing houses for their work.

There is value in hearing from citizen journalists or people on the scene not working for major news outlets, of course. And from people doing independent reporting on an ongoing basis (rather than around a single major news story that might generate a liveblog).

Liveblogs on major news sites get a lot of flak but, honestly? I really like them and they've made it much easier to part ways with Twitter as a "breaking news" engine. 

Why deal with the sludge when I can see live updates from actual journos on the scene, vetted by actual editors?

I've thought about this a lot since nuking my Twitter account in August, and I've come to two conclusions:

1) it is true that Bluesky is not a great place to follow breaking news as it happens

2) it does not affect my life at all to receive news a few hours later than people on twitter receive it

I disagree with the contention that we're 'letting' it happen. They're already being disrupted and broken through increased abuse and surveillance from extremists, through T&S being an afterthought and marginalised groups like trans people and sex workers being increasingly targeted by the company.

Ordinarily, I'd agree. But that kind of atomisation, which all of these platforms promote as a rule, is *really* not going to help us here. Individualism masquerading as 'community' got us into this mess.

That aside, I can't tell anyone what to do. I can only offer my considered view.

It's a massive platform *because* we're there, and disproportionately powerful and influential people are there. Without them and without us, it's 4chan. This is a cyclical argument I've long had problems with; Twitter is a valuable 'get' for Musk *because* we're on it. We're the value.

The analogy isn't precise, I know. Some people have said that there remains a larger international community on Twitter, and there may be some with valid business reasons for clinging on. But I don't think that describes most people.

It's not about changing *Musk's* mind but about reducing the vectors for the toxic sludge he and his fellow travellers are now producing at industrial scale. He's whipping up mobs against trans people, actively, for pity's sake.

I don't *blame* them, Noah. But if my bar got bought out by Nazis who then opened the place up to fash, yes I'd mourn, but I wouldn't then keep clinging to the place because of the fond memories. And I would look askance at anyone who did.

I always feel bad about having a similar reaction because, well, what am I going to do? Get annoyed about *language* with someone who can't make rent? 

But, on a broader level, it's frustrating to see yet more radical language get watered down into meaninglessness.

I'm sure that I could, if I were still plugging away at Twitter, get the engagement there I once did. I had to raise money recently even, and am trying to fund a project. But I still resisted. 

It's not about the engagement, it's about giving Musk's far-right carnival my blessing and amplification.

The people I call the "epistemic elite"--journos, academics, writers, artists, celebrities, politicos and so on--are the biggest risk here because they're the likeliest to launder Twitter BS into respectable venues that reach the vast majority of the public that is *not* on the platform.

At least one journalist I admire finally seemed to quit Twitter and move over here. He's still here, but he started posting on Twitter again recently, which saddens me. It's people like him who are, unfortunately, vectors for what makes Twitter such a threat to democracy.

Sites like 4chan still generate harm in the world, but few serious people feel the need to breathlessly report on its every lewd twitch. It is, to a large measure, contained in many ways that matter; it's not shaping mainstream discourse.

Twitter needs its own Chernobyl Sarcophagus, yesterday.

Or, even if they don't, those epistemic elites are *influenced* by Twitter's jaundicing, and they take an Extremely Online approach to the world to places it doesn't belong. All of which is bad for us.

"Colony collapse" is an excellent term for what needs to happen.

I keep saying this: Twitter is dangerous because decent people, normies, and people with media access all provide vectors for its BS into the outside world. This has always been a problem, but it's past criticality now.

Shitty ideas will spread through Twitter no matter what now. The point is to ensure that casual users and low engagement people don't go to Twitter thinking it's a place for viable information or conversation. The point is to ensure its only reputation is garbage. No one casually goes to 4chan.

One of the reasons GamerGate caused so much harm to its targets was because it (often accidentally) exploited the bias in media towards performative ethical disclosures about trivia while far larger ethical issues were either ignored or normalised as industry practise.
The inconsequential stuff allows for the pretence of unstinting principle, while the big picture problems can be normalised as the cost of doing business--or even as courageous journalism itself.

But that mirrors patterns in legacy media. The New York Times' reporting in the runup to the Iraq War? Its reporting on trans kids more recently? Loads of ethical issues there. But it's Caity Weaver nibbling off of Flo from Progressive's caviar that they have to fall over themselves to atone for?

This is why I keep analogising web design to road design. American roads aren't dangerous because we're worse people, it's because our roads promote unsafe driving (as do the designs of our most popular vehicles). Scolding people to drive better will avail us little. It's the same with social media.

This is, in the end, not about personal morality. It's about systems. We are in a system whose affordances make mutual policing easy, desirable, and even rewarding in various ways. If the only way to stop it is a pinky promise, it's doomed.

There will always be someone who presents too tempting a target, and each of us deludes ourselves into thinking our one little comment, our one subtweet, doesn't constitute harassment. The mote of dust doesn't see the haboob it's a part of.

The problem isn't unique to us, of course. It's a problem with the internet as a whole, and social media specifically. It bites hardest on marginalised groups because we're fighting for scraps and confronting implicit biases and internalised prejudice/self-loathing, but it affects *everyone.*

The thing I object to is the idea that if GamerGate didn't happen, the world would've been saved (which is a serious idea I've seen bandied about). GG built on existing extremism strategies that were already in force on sites like Stormfront, e.g., or the way ISIS used Twitter.

I heard there was a secret cord

But you don't really want to save it, do ya

I also feel like a lot of the mainstream press coverage wasn't imaginative about the right-wing radicalisation threat, nor how this was a harbinger of things to come in anything like the same way.

(Also I love your username. Great reference. ;) )

I think by the time you hit the end of 2014 and into early 2015 there was definitely more coverage for sure. But I wrote one of the first non-gaming-media pieces about it in September of 2014, and it was a bit like shouting in the wilderness. It took time to get noticed.
But it *was* a warning sign about the far-right trying new vectors for radicalisation and recruitment.

In general, though, I feel like a lot of journalists are trying to expiate the sin of ignoring GamerGate at the time by overstating its influence now. GG was the product of reactionary forces already swirling around (like the Tea Party, etc.); had it not been GG, it would've been something else.

GamerGate did motivate individuals to do awful things, though, a few of which intruded into people's physical lives--and it was, deliberately, a gateway drug to the far-right. Hells, that's why Breitbart, Steve Bannon et al. got so into it.

GG did not create the alt-right (a claim some serious people have made) nor did it directly lead to Trump's election. But it was a radicalising force for its participants. That it inspired a would-be far-right assassin is exactly the sort of thing we would've expected GG to do.

As someone who lived through GamerGate, was a major target of theirs, and who analysed and reported on the campaign, I've long been in the camp that GG's overall importance is frequently overstated (it was a product of, not a cause of political reaction). But on an *individual* level? Yeah... this.

A lot of the doomsaying is, in a perverse way, therapeutic for people. They're venting. They're sad. They're angry. They're despairing. 

But when you scream into a pillow at home, it only affects you. When you do it on open social media, it becomes *information.*

This is where social media being therapy/catharsis is entirely at crosspurposes with social media as a movement builder.

In fact, it frequently *demobilises* because it channels and amplifies some of our uglier emotional needs at the expense of all else.

It's worth remembering that the big influencer transphobes can feel popular and pervasive thanks to the way social media works. Even microminorities can get very loud megaphones here. But this can create a false impression of how widespread or popular they or their views actually are.

This needs to be repeated loudly and often as, if nothing else, an antidote to the despair that can be inculcated by being stuck in social media's oubliette of terror.

The transphobic extremists *feel* pervasive, and they have powerful friends. But they are not popular.

So yes, I find the Discourse annoying and frequently wanting in political literacy. It's also entirely toothless. Yelling at its purveyors won't win tranches of votes for Dems. If you sincerely believe in the power of voting, volunteer, rally your friends, phone-bank, knock on doors. That helps.

The Discourse, meanwhile, is fundamentally narcissistic. Someone acting like they have something of value and, occasionally, taking a perverse pleasure in making others beg and yell at them for it. Nothing changes, of course. Their vote will not sway Wisconsin. But it makes for great Content!

There's issues of access and voter suppression; an inability (or unwillingness) to be informed; private idiosyncrasies; unfortunate coincidences; or a political disenchantment that has nothing to do with a microminority of communist shitposters.

The reasons that a lot of people in the US don't vote--including an alarming number of young people--don't have much to do with 'principled' radikewl Discoursing on places like this. Most people aren't here (or on Twitter). They neither know nor care. Their reasons for not voting are their own.

It's lab-grown social media silliness. A fundamentally meaningless affair that can inspire loud, angry, continuous debate on both sides--occasionally good points are made on either end, but nothing ever changes. 

It's ideal microblogging fodder.

Since it's, yet again, Voting Discourse O'Clock, I think it's worth reminding everyone of something:

Yes, the "rofl rofl Dems and the GOP are exactly the same, why bother voting!?" people are extremely annoying.

They also influence nothing and yelling at them is pointless.

Wisconsin isn't being won or lost because of the "early 20s cosplay tankie shitposter" vote, to be quite honest. So it always seemed like wasted effort all around, just generating a lot of pointless outrage for the sake of pointless outrage.

The *actual* percentage of gettable votes that's made up of the kind of cosplay revolutionary who gets on a microblogging site to have Discourse about the eebil, mean ol' liberals who think voting is the universal cure-all? Microscropic.

I do think there's truth this--why would they care so much if it didn't bother them on some visceral level?

But also, as much sympathy as I have with the "vote-shamers" I think the people they yell at are so insignificant in the grand scheme of things.

Bluesky 3 months ago felt as if the showrunners had said “what if Shanley’s 2016 ‘stop appropriating daddy’ twitter meltdown was turned into a theme park where it was just Like That that every day?”

This whole "BSky was so good back in the OLD days" is codswollop. But so is the idea that the site is better now. It's just different, and the toxicity it mass-produces is pretty much the same, just operating at a larger scale and with different reference points.

Equally, the popular BSky cope of "well, you have to *work* for engagement here, and these old Twitter elites are shocked that they're unpopular here!" is proving less true by the day as popular Twitter accounts decamp here with comparable audiences.

Twitter's unique brand of toxic sincerity, meanwhile, is definitely making a huge comeback here. Asinine reply guys, mansplainers by the dozen, people getting angry at you for things you didn't say, et cetera.

Contemporary BSky has more Very Serious, Important people here, who wrinkle their nose at Alf hog and catgirl lewds, etc. 

The epistemic elite are trying to recreate the addictive illusion of collegiality that they had on Twitter.

Nevertheless, since there's now a discussion about this: I think current BSky is more closely resembling Twitter in ways that are both good and (mostly) bad, while early BSky was good and (mostly) bad in a more unique way caused by its small-town dynamics.

The hilarious thing was that when Dril tried to post here, he *did* actually stop being funny, as if the way early BSky waxed and waned between septic sincerity and excessive shitpostiness had somehow assimilated him.

The companion bias here is excessive faith in the efficacy of individual action. "If only you jabronis didn't share plaintext codes there wouldn't *be* any Nazis here!" 

Why believe that? Well, because it's possible with the platform's affordances. Therefore it *must* do something. ...Right?
Oh I figured as much, it was for the benefit of others. In case it's not clear, I'm agreeing with you!

But to answer Cardiogram's question--why spool this out for days?--it's because it's what platforms like this do. If the solution is to shame people into doing X (because that's all the platform really lets you do), then the solution to them not doing so is to shame harder and beef about it all day.

I shared several posts urging people not to post codes in plaintext, it's true. But it's primarily because I didn't want to help bot farms, nor have friends waste their codes. 

The people who think it's some kind of special sauce that determines whether or not Nazis show up here are... not correct.

In microblogging there's a strong bias towards individualistic shaming--because that's the main thing that the platform's affordances permit you to do with any kind of activism. So... one desperately needs to pretend it works and is effective.

Yeah, the latter is the thing. The site's influence derived from the fact that powerful people who were *themselves* influential obsessed over the site's happenings. We don't think of Tumblr as shaping the outcome of elections because Wolf Blitzer isn't there 24/7.

AI people like to talk about ChatGPT "hallucinating" when it makes things up. I dislike the term because it anthropomorphises LLMs in unhelpful ways.

But Twitter made epistemic elites hallucinate in the same fashion. That's the extent of its influence.

From my perspective, that tastemaking ability frequently gave the media brainworms. It mass-manufactured bogus-trend stories, and also fed things like obsessive transphobia on the part of certain journalists and writers.

I think there's a few ideas getting confounded here.

Are we talking about changing the world? Or are we talking about talking? Tastemaking's not nothing, but it's far from the whole ballgame many people pretend it is.
Many people are saying this!
If the fear is that Musk will combine Twitter at the height of its powers with the extremist echo chamber of 8chan, rest easy. You can have one or the other, but not both. Musk made his choice.

It's *that* level of importance that is rapidly declining on Twitter. The ability to be newsworthy in its own right and to dominate the minds of powerful people in the world's media centres, boardrooms, and capitals. It's *that* spell that is (thank Christ) finally being broken.

The final stage of its evolution is going to be something like Gab, Stormfront, KF, or 8chan. It *will* remain a place that will cause problems. Mass killings will be planned there. This is a huge, ongoing problem. 

But those sites don't set media agendas like Twitter used to.

Why do you think the man has to beg Taylor Swift or *checks notes* Russell Brand to use the platform more? Twitter had two things: an audience and a lot of users among the "epistemic elite." Its failing reputation is pushing both away.

Stancil analogises Twitter to Fox News; not unreasonable, but Twitter doesn't have White House Press Corps credentials. It's not a profitable legacy news organisation owned by an equally profitable Death Star of a congolmerate. Even Musk can't pay enough to artificially inflate Twitter's relevance.
Hah, an excellent way of putting it. This is why I keep yelling at "important" people to log the fuck off from Twitter.

Twitter's destiny is to become a site that generates nastiness--like a subreddit that foments harassment off-platform--but not the essential forum that demanded academics, journos, politicians, activists, artists, etc put a Twitter handle on their business card. Those days are over.

And thank fuck.

I don't dispute that Twitter is still coasting on its reputation, and there are still too many organisations, celebrities, businesses, and media personalities maintaining a presence there. But the more of them leave, the more Twitter becomes like 4chan. Bad, yes, but not influential in the same way.

To offer a good faith critique here: 

The problem is that Twitter is relevant because it (was) diverse but also packed to the gills with too many media people and politicos who cared what went on there and turned site drama into international news. If they decamp, Twitter becomes less relevant.

"Bluesky was great until the last batch of new people".
This has been said every week since I got here in March

I'm on the record as being deeply skeptical, unfortunately. 

The day the wall around the site comes down will not be a good one. However much Bluesky thinks they're preparing, they're not ready.

I do think that, as reality has set in, Bluesky has had to take a more active top-down approach than they originally envisioned.

But, I suppose, just keep bringing bad actors to their attention?

If for no other reason than that 

*Fascists are forced to harass grassroots good faith volunteer moderators, to achieve their goals of rolling up control of communications channels*

— you should be kind to anyone who does real moderation service

The trick to good community moderation is that the platform still has to provide institutional support. Tools and backup. Resources. Hell, lets go bananas here and say *pay* as well. But if you cut people loose, they get none of the benefits, all the scrutiny, and things go wrong.

In a sense, democratic scrutiny is good and healthy here--questioning and challenging the lists. But applying that scrutiny to a private person is very different from doing so with a corporation. And yet it's what everyone--Kairi, Bree, whoever helps/succeeds them--is signing up for. It's not fun.

Perhaps the "waah" was mislaid (ah, the things microblogging forces upon us). 

But the larger point is that you can't satisfy everyone. A mutelist is a convenience, but you can still mute people on your own.

I'll also add two things here.

1) This is what fills the vacuum of platform governance on a place like Bluesky; it, in some ways, represents BSky's failure to assume greater responsibility.

2) Bluesky is designed to slough off the labour of moderation onto you. It's *this* all the way down, folks.

People on sites like this one tend to be a fickle and ungrateful lot. And a volunteer moderation role quickly becomes a thankless lodestone for wankers--a lightning rod of all the obvious drama.

"Waaah, I'm on this mutelist!"

"Waaah, I'm less safe because you took X off the mutelist!"

It is thankless, frequently unpleasant, risky, turbulent and dramatic. Mistakes will be made. Choices to protect one's self must be made sometimes. All for the competitive salary of zero dollars and zero cents.

At the risk of sounding painfully twee: be graceful and be kind.

Community moderation is also vulnerable to biases aplenty, and if only a handful of people are doing it, that's a serious potential point of failure.

But if you're just an ordinary user of the site, it means you should reserve grace for the people who *volunteer* for this role.

It becomes a microcosm of all the unsavoury controversy, the unbearable responsibility that bedevils Big Tech firms and their moderation decisions. You will never make everybody happy.

Except you're not a multi-billion dollar corporation. There's no bank for you to laugh all the way to.

People on sites like this one tend to be a fickle and ungrateful lot. And a volunteer moderation role quickly becomes a thankless lodestone for wankers--a lightning rod of all the obvious drama.

"Waaah, I'm on this mutelist!"

"Waaah, I'm less safe because you took X off the mutelist!"

And 3) when people have an active stake in their community, they are likelier to behave better and do the kind of ground-level work that top-down moderation/platform governance cannot easily achieve (if at all.)

But...

Organic, grassroots community moderation is important for a few reasons. 1) It's just a marker of a healthy platform. People care enough to try and take care of it on their own time, 2) a community that takes responsibility for itself will be likelier to thrive...

My fiancee was brave enough to protest the attack on Afghanistan on *9/12* and she still has dark memories about how people in a liberal city treated her for doing so.

I'm ashamed to say that, though I was 14 on 9/11, it took me until the eve of the Iraq War to fully appreciate what was going on.

The swerve I experienced in America itself was frightening to behold. One minute "we're all Americans" the next we were encouraged to spy on our neighbours.

It really felt like everything was coming apart at the seams.

Anyway, I laughed sometimes. I'm not calling anyone evil here. Or I'd be calling myself out too. But beneath all this discourse it's worth being clear-eyed about what this is really about, what it's really for, and the limits of what social media can do against the enormity of post-9/11 evils.

In the end, it's just another way of pretending our therapeutic use of social media is Politics. That our catharsis is some radical effort against the world's evils.

But you're just alone with yourself--and perhaps desensitizing yourself to tragedy. Not ideal for these times.

In using the memes as deprogramming--as a reaction to the onslaught of militarism and imperialism that exploded from America in 9/11's wake--I can respect it as an individual exercise. But using that to say images of innocent people dying are funny because praxis is just over the top, though.

The memes are not a grievous wound or harm. I even find some funny. But they're more of the same emotional detritus that constitutes social media's chief export. Empty calorie catharsis that we then seek to ennoble.

Part and parcel of an edgelord culture online whose only practical effect is to glorify the hardening of hearts, that glories in making the "right people" "mad" and pretending there's praxis in there somewhere.

And for those of us who were in New York at the time, who did live through that and experienced the human element of loss there, the memes can seem... at best, weird, and at worst stomping on the graves of people who were not responsible for what came next.

To me, it's also kind of pointless.

This is what the memes respond to, what they seek to pervert with wild irreverence. The imperial image that justified all that.

But there's the second layer to 9/11: the actual, real tragedy as experienced by New Yorkers. It *was* an event where real, innocent people died, often horribly.

And in the name of that 9/11 Imaginary, that heightened sensitivity where this was all some phantom pain every American walked wounded with, incalculable violence and destruction was rained on several other countries--and on innocent civilians here at home. Pain, heaped atop more pain.

There would be, he warned, brief mention of a plane hitting the Twin Towers. It came from an architect interviewed who said that the WTC was designed to withstand a blow from a B707, the largest jet aircraft that existed when the towers were designed.

This needed a warning. Madness.

There was also this odd sensitivity it sired. I'll never forget watching an A&E documentary about the building of the Twin Towers, filmed before 9/11, that was somberly introduced by a presenter who gave us what would, years, later be called a trigger warning.

There are two layers to 9/11. One is what we might call the 9/11 Imaginary, the way the image was used to justify mass murder many times over; the jingoism; the "Proud to be an American!" madness; the explosion of Islamophobia and other bigotries that it justified in the population.

The 9/11 memes come from a couple of different places. 1) A need to deprogram a shibboleth of empire. 2) Among younger people, a lack of lived memory. 3) Among older people, a cleansing of a stain that got all over us, 4) sticking one in the eye of self-serious imperialists.

But.

Think about Mr. Good Vibes Only, that guy I criticised the other night for his cringey post; he was "helping," he was responding to a blazingly bad faith callout. But all he did was spread a different type of toxicity, and lent life to the Discourse cycle that whole, wider mishegas spawned.

The more you talk about someone who's been wrongly Main Character'd, the more you help sustain the storm swirling around them. That storm is made up of one thing only: attention. So, even if you intervene to defend them--"no, she's a good gal!"--you're merely creating another Discourse vector.

If you're being slandered by some clout-chaser, the best thing people can do is not believe them. But dogpiling them with counter-abuse, memes, etc. doesn't actually do very much. The problem endemic to these platforms is that there *is* no healthy mode of interaction afforded to you.

There's truth to this, but there's a deeper, sadder truth: I think some people fail to intervene out of fear, but others recognise it's futile. Because what, actually, is "help"? More Discourse for the sake of Discourse. "no u" stomping on your face forever.

And I do think Musk relished the idea of taking revenge on his critics, for sure. You're right. But that behaviour is very surface-level, it's not a villainous master plan. It's the same kind of impulse-driven narcissism we see from Trump.

Yeah, that's another tragically apposite example. Honestly, as someone who's researched in this space for over a decade now, I've come to believe that the idea that "social media did X Bad Thing, so it must have an equal ability to perform its opposite, Y Good Thing" is tragically mistaken.
I assumed good faith but I appreciate you being thoughtful about how that came across!

But I'd contend that the awful things it did related to individual behaviour, not structural change. Unfortunately Twitter was massively better at getting you to hate another person/group than organising positive, slow, constructive change. Thus, a better fit for right-wing rather than leftist goals
Twitter has done horrible things--which does rather make the point, contra Collins, that the power elite needed to neuter it.

We can point to activists appropriating technologies in ways that afford them new capabilities, yes (Indian revolutionaries and railways, e.g.) But the railroad analogy here is the internet *itself*, not a specific platform.

And I think that's the other thing that bugs me about Collins' arguments in this vein. It implies the loss of Twitter is some kind of Ragnarok for truly effective activism; it isn't. Activists, time and time again, MacGuyver the solutions they need.

It is. But I think it's diminishing to attribute BLM *to* Twitter, as well, as some people do. Activists use the tools available to them; had Twitter not existed, some other medium would've sufficed for the online components or organising.

To say nothing of how the "Musk bought Twitter to kneecap activists" theory is, again, imputing 3D chess manoeuvring to a manifestly stupid man. What about his investors? I wouldn't want to go on record arguing they're *much* smarter than Musk here.

And that, more than anything else, is what Twitter refined into an art form. The exceptions--movements like BLM--became exceptions because of how deeply rooted in the physical world they were. But most everything else was just Extremely Online BS we pretended was important.

Do you know why I truly hate Discourse? It's not because it's insipid, often objectively wrong, or even personally harmful (though that's all Very Bad). It's because it became a commodity; the thing that convinced even radicals to keep logging on and giving their value away to tech companies.

It's funny that Collins compares it to a complaint line because in some ways that's exactly what it was. An anti-information system whose entire purpose was to bleed away popular dissent into individuals shouting at each other while the truly powerful kept counting their money.

What Twitter did was convince a bunch of people that low-effort shitposting was activism. That didn't hurt the power elite, it *enabled* them. Activist fervor and popular dissent were just more solids capitalism melted into air.

Providing advice to people who want to make the jump is one thing. Holding it up as the only solution is another. And dear Goddess I am sick of Americans and Canadians who move to Europe and never shut up about how great it is being upper middle class and white there.

Other people are already saying this at length, but you can't handwave this by acknowledging "I know it's privileged," the way he does. It *is* deeply insulting to people who can't leave. And even if you *have* money the calculus for moving to Europe is *very* different as a POC &/or trans person.

Having stated his thesis this boldly here, it does kind of make the channel harder to watch now, unfortunately. He can say what he likes, but I'd rather not watch a channel run by a guy who thinks my home is fit only for abandonment, you know? *shrugs*

I've frequently joked with one of my best friends that his channel must be an op by Amsterdam's tourism board. But I had hoped that he'd have the good sense to not actually *believe* that "moving to Europe" was the solution to all problems, and that this was just a bit.

The other points that NJB makes in his thread are not exactly wrong. No YT channel should be expected to do everything, people can and should "outgrow" certain channels, et cetera. That's all very true.

I don't think that means this smug expat perspective is defensible though.

There's a certain smugness attending this personality; one that flattens complex issues, and where the universal solvent is just "move to Europe!" As if it's free of problems. Yes, its public transportation is a lot better on average; many other things are quite catastrophically bad.

So, I don't want to dogpile here. I've loved the Not Just Bikes channel for a long time but it feels like the things I *didn't* like just came to a head here--namely that there's a particular type of North American who moves to Europe and gets, well, like this.

I kept my old middle name because it sounded androgynous, but years later I added "Alejandra" because I wanted to re-anchor my name in my heritage. When I write, I want it to be clear a Latina wrote this.

A name is dignity, and naming one's self is power.

There were added complications. I was named after my father. (To this day, changing my surname is something he struggles with). And I also have mixed feelings in hindsight about changing my last name from a Spanish surname to an English one.

I had the same relationship to my old name that I do to my SSN: a series of glyphs that signified "me" but had no emotional value beyond that. When I changed my name--first and last--it felt more important than even starting HRT. The true before/after dividing line.

This, in turn, leads to politicising *everything* online. Every emotion, every quirk of one's day, every taste, every innocuous opinion, becomes fodder for some Ragnarok-esque debate about humanity. And even the people who knowingly make fun of it, who are savvy, keep participating.

So it's not even a chicken and egg question. Social media created an environment of incentives where "let's get X trending!" became a soothing substitute for real activism. Which then breeds more of the same and influences activist narratives as they try to justify this course.

Social media excels at "performative rather than substantive." It can't meaningfully change the world at the structural level--not very easily, anyway. But it's good at symbolism. Words, arguments, images. So it's easy to focus (or fixate) on that.

I've been an online tranny since 2009. I've watched this cycle happen so many times in every direction--and, regrettably, did my part in fostering and perpetuating it. 

Twitter-esque microblogging didn't create this. But it dramatically accelerates the cycles.

They say something incredibly stupid or offensive because they weren't working on themselves. And then they get set upon for self-hatred or false-allyship or whatever by the very people who created the system of social incentives that led the person to that place to begin with.

But that's 101. The more complex issue is that people acting in *good faith* get trapped by those rules as well. Instead of focusing on fixing their implicit biases, they focus on mastering rules in order to fit in. And it works. Right up until it doesn't.

Slogans are necessary for quickly communicating activist ideas. They're standards under which you rally people. But, let's be real, too often those slogans become axioms. Inflexible rules that must be followed--and, therefore, create a series of cheat codes for bad actors.

But as to the more crowdsourced COINTELPRO-esque stuff Bree is alluding to, it's been going on for years. Just look at the Your Slip is Showing affair from a decade ago.

But the easily-exploited, Extremely Online lefty axioms and norms have barely changed since.

They most certainly do, and do so openly.

Indeed, the far-right avails itself of identity politics in the worst faith imaginable. "'Believe X Voices,' you say? Ho ho, here's a member of X and he's on our board, *and* a Holocaust denier! Checkmate, libs!"

I am not convinced that a better comm strategy will do much in the longrun to ameliorate the burgeoning toxicity here. But it is almost certainly ethical to improve comms for their own sake--and to at least *try* Rahaeli's hypothesis.

As Bluesky grows, it'll become harder and harder and harder to manage this sort of thing. People are already reporting that the site has changed drastically over the last few weeks. Some of this is digital psychosomatism, but I think there's also some truth to it. And it's down to population growth.

Even now you have people on this platform acting in bad faith, ginning up mobs to try and take down popular posters in the latest round of Tall Poppy Syndrome that plagued Twitter for years. That's not at all easy to moderate, and a comm strategy doesn't dent that at all.

And an open, Twitter-like platform that thrives on vast everyone-to-everyone 'conversations,' is invariably going to get sucked into these rage dynamics as the population grows larger because it'll always be easy for some faction to gin up the requisite energy using these viral tools.

Because while I agree with Rahaeli that your comm strategy does, over time, help shape the response you get from your users... there is a lot (too much) to be said about how the platform itself shapes and incentivises certain kinds of community.

That remains to be seen. More darkly, it remains to be seen whether it's even possible on a microblogging platform that purports to be open and viral.

If there's hope, it lies in Rahaeli and Rudy's suggestions. But I am not optimistic that we can make this medium work.

Can this platform, this medium, and the corporate structure of their startup *channel* that caring appropriately? It isn't about the private virtue of individuals--even Jay Graber herself. It's about whether they've set up a system to translate their caring into real, positive change here.

Does BSky give a damn? A lot of people say no, but I don't believe that at all. We do have to face the fact that we live in an imperfect, complex world---and well-meaning, passionate people can and do make horrible mistakes sometimes.

I think a lot of BSky staff care very deeply.

With that in mind, this apology could've been far, far worse. But what really matters are the next steps. And I remain deeply worried about the ongoing vagueness about T&S. A dedicated account for comms is nice. But I need to see more hires and structure.

Bluesky is a startup, so they're going to ride the "we're just a smolbean company, just a little guy" excuse for as long as they possibly can. 

But they have the mindset of a social media company--in part because they have to--and so my expectations are always low.

At that point, on this kind of platform, you're incentivised heavily to write something dry, polished, and box-ticking--which is what Graber's apology post felt like. To be more intimate/personal is to invite further attack; different groups will take away different messages.

My initial impression? About as good as we can expect from the Bluesky team right now. I take Rahaeli's point about "matching the intensity of the userbase" but I'm not sure that's possible on this kind of platform (Dreamwidth is qualitatively different from microblogging, after all.)
I'm still thinking about the apology post and incident report from today and I hope to assemble some of my own thoughts on the matter soon.

This dovetails neatly with Rudy's suggestion here of open community forums. Rahaeli's whole point is that you need to continually demonstrate to the userbase that there are productive avenues for change *besides* Turn It Up to 11 rageposting. And this is an excellent suggestion for one such avenue.

OMG a hit skeet.

For all the hagiography that's already being written about Bluesky being a lovely place for forming connections, etc. etc., *that* showed what a lot of people were really after. A Main Character. Mensch earned it. Plenty of others won't. And so it goes.

This is why Louse Mensch's intro post got so many replies. Sure, she's a hideous excuse for a human being who, in an abstract moral sense, deserved to get the pooping pig image posted at her.

It also did nothing valuable, save show what kind of posting people really want to do.

If Bluesky is to have a future, this needs to end. But it probably won't. The cultural incentives, combined with the platform's affordances (and the affordances of similar microblogging clones) push things in this direction.

One can use social media as a component of activism, but Twitter, more than any other platform (yes, even Tumblr), made posting an end in itself. A self-referential Ouroboros of ever more obscure shit/posting that convinced itself of its praxis.

But that's the genesis of the "poster strike," the genesis of "is it okay to like this?" the genesis of reading the tea leaves of every dev post for some hidden truth about the platform...

The false hope that posting is activism.

A lot of what's happening here seems to be a desperate attempt to recapture the already-shattered dream that if you yell at enough people On Here you'll change something meaningful about the world. Goddess knows I was tempted by that dream for too many wasted years.

And this, among other toxic practices, suggests something particularly bleak about the various Twitter clones. The one, truly important thing they have in common, despite their endless guttersniping at one another: each is just a stage of grief for the loss of Twitter.

The truly maladaptive behaviour that's coming to predominate on here, however, is the fact that a lot of people are retreating into the same bad habits of mistaking engagement for activism. 

"Let's get X trending!" is not a call for meaningful change.

At the risk of being hideously controversial, every time I browse here I increasingly see this place as a slightly nicer Twitter. 

Fewer Nazis, for sure, despite Bluesky's lackadaisical moderation. But otherwise circular firing squads of gestural activism aplenty.
